text:
Irving Place, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of East 15th Street (right), showing at the corner, the Irving Place Theatre. This structure was known as Amberg's Theatre in 1892, which opened here in 1888 and at which the Muenchener Company played on November 5, 1890. Upon this site formerly stood Irving Hall, opened December 20, 1860 for balls, lectures and concerts, and which was famous as a rendezvous for one faction of the Democratic party, to which it gave its name. Today (1938), this building is given over to Burlesque performances, a feature which aroused local interest when Judge Crain was District Attorney of Manhattan recently; this and adjoining property being in his family for years. A negative print accompanies this, forming a set of two.

About 1900.

Irving Place, west side, 15th to 16th Streets, inclusive, showing the clearing on the site of the old Westminster   Hotel on the N.W. corner of  16th Street, where the new Borgfeldt Building is about to be erected. The Hotel Du Nord, shown on the N.W. corner of 15th Street has only recently been known by that name, from around 1890 to after 1902.  This was the older Hotel America. (now at 102-06 East 16th St); In 1885 it was Hotel del Recreo, and in 1879 Belvedere House (probably its original name).

This building will finally be replaced around 1928 by a new 4-story structure called the Irving Plaza.  The houses above it, 21-33 Irving Place, will be demolished shortly after the time of this picture to make place for the 12-story structure later to be known as the Nemo Building.

March 1909
Brown Brothers

Transcribers note: March 1909 appears to be the date of the photo. The information supplied for it appears to have been compiled decades later (Or else by a clairvoyant).

117-119 East 15th Street, adjoining N.W. corner of Irving Place.
About 1911.

A general view south along Third Ave., from Irving Place at the S.E. corner of 15th Street (between Third Ave., and Union Square East).

September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
A general view, north from Irving Place, at the S.E. corner of 15th Street, (between Third Ave., and Union Square East), showing buildings from left to right, the Metropolitan Life Insurance (Madison Ave., and 23rd Street);, Empire State, (under completion), (Fifth Ave., and 34th St)., Chrysler, (Lexington Ave., and 42nd St) and the New York Daily News Building, (42nd St., between Second and Third Aves). The Third Ave., Elevated Lines are shown at the right.

September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - [Manhattan - Irving Place - 15th Street (Southeast) - Between 3rd Avenue and Union Square.]

title: General view - [Manhattan - Irving Place - 15th Street (Southeast) - Between 3rd Avenue and Union Square.]

text:
(1) A general view, northeast from Irving Place, at the S.E. corner of 15th Street, (between Third Ave., and Union Square East). (Irving Place extends from 14th Street, north to 20th Street, between Third and Fourth Aves). (Union Square East, is a continuation south of Fourth Ave., from 17th to 14th Streets). The view shows the Third Ave., Elevated Lines, the Chrysler (Lexington Ave., and 42nd St., and New York Daily News, 42nd St., between Second and Third Aves). Buildings in the distance and also the East River at the right. September 23, 1930. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, another view. September 23, 1930. P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - [Manhattan - Irving Place - 15th Street (Southeast) - Between 3rd Avenue and Union Square.]

George D. Chinn.

August, 1938
George D. Chinn
